runninghead.i: Chapter 59 Muysken and Veenstra: Serial Verbs
Chapter 59 Muysken and Veenstra: Serial Verbs

li.p: Absence of verbal morphology and separation of verbs from INFL

subsection.heading: 1 Introduction
subsection.p: The phenomenon of verb serialization has been informally characterized as “a row of verbs one after another ...[in which] the verbs stand next to each other without being connected” (Westerman 1930: 126). Serial verb constructions typically have the following format:
(1) NP1 V1 NP2 V2 (XP3) (X = N, P)

Defined in such a way, the notion of verb serialization is rather vague. Many scholars, therefore, have tried to make this notion more precise (cf. Jansen et al. 1978; Sebba 1987; Muysken 1988; Baker 1989; Seuren 1991; among many others). Several syntactic and, to a lesser extent, semantic criteria have played a role in the discussion on the definition of serial verb constructions. It must be noted beforehand that it has never led to much agreement.

Depending on the criteria chosen, serial verbs are either (i) a particular family of constructions, restricted to some language families, or (ii) a phenomenon found to some extent in all languages. Besides the classical examples in the Greenberg–Kwa languages of Niger-Congo (cf. Awóyalé 1988), and in creole languages in the Caribbean (Jansen et al. 1978; Sebba 1987), the construction is also arguably present in Chinese, Japanese, and Korean (Chinese: C. Li and Thompson 1973; Y. Li 1990b, 1993, 1998; Sybesma 1992; Zou 1993, 1994a, 1994b; J. Li 1997; Japanese: Kuno 1973c; Kageyama 1993; Nishiyama 1998; Korean: Lee 1994), and at the limit in Germanic languages (so-called fake-coordinate VPs in which both verbs agree in the tense specification without an overt subject before V2 – see for English: Carden and Pesetsky 1977; Goldsmith 1985; Lakoff 1986; Swedish: Anward 1988; Norwegian: Åfarli and Creider 1987; Den Dikken 1991a, 1991b). In addition, Schiller (1991) has found serial verb constructions in the following language families: Hmong-Mien (Court 1985), Mon-Khmer (Phillips 1973; Kuhn 1990), Oceanic (Durie 1988, 1997), Tai-Kadai (Thepkanjana 1986), Papuan (Pawley 1980), and Semitic (Hussein 1990).

To start, we confine our discussion to examples from Saramaccan, a creole language spoken in Suriname, making supplementary reference to facts from other Atlantic creoles and from some of the better-studied languages of Greenberg–Kwa.
Serial verb constructions display a wide variety of readings, as can be seen from the following illustrative examples:

(2)
a. A tjá hen gó a dí dáata.
3SG carry 3SG go LOC DET doctor
‘He went to the doctor with her.’
b. A sindjó nján.
3SG sit.down eat
‘He sat down and ate.’
c. A náki hen kíi.
3SG hit 3SG kill
‘He hit it dead.’
In (2a) the verb tjá introduces a comitative; (2b) expresses two sequential events; and (2c) translates as a resultative construction. Cf. the following:

(3)
a. A bígi pása mi.
3SG big exceed 1SG
‘He is bigger than me.’
b. A wáka lóntu dí wósu.
3SG walk surround DET house
‘He walked around the house.’
c. A téi dí fáka kóti dí beée.
3SG take DET knife cut DET bread
‘He cut the bread with the knife.’ [approx.]

(3a) is an example of a comparative construction; in (3b) the verb lóntu specifies the location/direction of the event of the first verb; and in (3c) the verb téi introduces an instrumental adjunct. In all cases in (2) and (3) one can say that the two verbs together express a single (albeit complex) event, which is assigned one truth-value.

In most studies, the underlying assumption has been that verb serialization is a unified phenomenon. This is, however, not an entirely uncontroversial position (cf. Veenstra 1989; Den Dikken 1991a, 1991b). The question is whether verb serialization as such constitutes a valid domain of investigation. Muysken (1988: 65) observes that it may be the case that “in the face of new and apparently contradictory data sets on serial verb constructions becoming available, . . . a unified phenomenon is fractured into odd bits and pieces.”

The most interesting question serial verb constructions pose for grammatical theory is, in our opinion, how their lexical and syntactic properties interact. On the one hand, they appear to be lexically determined: (i) the combinatory possibilities are partly lexically restricted, e.g., only verbs of movement can be followed by gó ‘go’ and kó ‘come’ expressing direction away from or toward a point of reference established in the discourse; (ii) they can form idiomatic expressions, e.g., the combination láfu NP kíi ‘laugh DP kill’ takes on the meaning of ‘deride DP’; and (iii) they often appear to undergo thematic restructuring to form complex predicates (which in most cases give rise to the phenomenon of ‘argument sharing’), a potential example being (2c). On the other hand, the individual verbs are clearly separate verbs assigning cases and thematic roles to intervening arguments. Also, the different verbs may denote different subevents, as in (2b). Several interrelated issues, therefore, arise in the analysis of serial verb constructions, among which the following will be touched upon in this chapter:

(4)
a. Lexicon/syntax and argument sharing: Is verb serialization a syntactic process or should it be accounted for by lexical operations on argument structure? How to account for ‘argument-sharing’ effects?
b. Concatenation: If serial verb constructions form chains, what are their concatenation principles, and what is the structural configuration involved?
c. Correspondence: To which constructions in non-serializing languages do serial verb constructions correspond?
d. Typological correlates: How do we account for the difference between serializing and non-serializing languages?

Crucial to (4a) is the issue of argument sharing. Is argument sharing taken care of in the lexicon, as it would be in a lexical analysis, or is the argument-sharing effect mediated through empty categories in serial verb complements, as it would be in a syntactic analysis?

With respect to (4b), three possible concatenation principles are suggested in the literature: coordination (e.g., Hale 1991), subordination (e.g., Jansen et al. 1978; Sebba 1987), and adjunction (e.g., Bickerton and Iatridou 1987; Larson 1991; Law and Veenstra 1992).

The correspondence issue of (4c) has received ample attention. Possible candidates that have been mentioned are asymmetric coordinations (e.g., Den Dikken 1991a, 1991b; Déchaine 1993; Corne et al. 1996), verb–preposition combinations (e.g., Muysken 1988), and secondary predication constructions (e.g., Muysken 1988; Den Dikken 1991a; Larson 1991; Law and Veenstra 1992).

If there exists something like a serializing language type (4d), we would expect a number of typological correlates (i.e., co-occurring linguistic features) of serial verb constructions. The following have been put forward as possible correlates: absence of verbal (derivational or inflectional) morphology; non-distinctiveness of verbs and prepositions (in terms of verbs as either additional Case markers – e.g., Bickerton 1981; Byrne 1987 – or additional markers of thematic roles – e.g., Sebba 1984), and separation of verbs from INFL (e.g., Muysken 1988; Larson 1991; Law and Veenstra 1992; Déchaine 1993).

In addition, does the difference between serializing and non-serializing languages come about by means of different options of a single parameter or through different ways of doing syntax and morphology? The parametric option is argued for by Baker (1989, 1991b) and Collins (1995a), while Larson (1991), Law and Veenstra (1992), and Déchaine (1993), among others, argue for a modular approach to verb serialization.

Here we will try to give a first inventory of these constructions and of the analytical problems that they raise, and discuss some of the analyses proposed so far. In section 2 we present a first definition, and in section 3 an enumeration of frequently occurring types of serial verb constructions. In section 4 we discuss the different possible structures proposed for the serial verb constructions and section 5 is dedicated to the problem of ‘shared arguments’: one noun phrase sometimes appears to belong to different verbs. Section 6 is aimed at the problem of typology and parameterization: what makes serial verb constructions possible in a language?

subsection.heading: 2 Definition
subsection.p: In the study of serial verb constructions, several criteria are implicitly used for what a serial verb construction really is. Generally they amount to something like the following. A serial verb construction contains two verbs which have:
We will illustrate each characteristic with examples from Saramaccan.

(5a) says that only one NP in the verbal chain that can be interpreted as a subject, i.e., is overtly realized in a subject position. (5b) refers to the ‘object-sharing’ phenomenon first observed by Stewart (1963) on the basis of Twi. This is exemplified in (6):

(6)
Dí kambósa bì tá sibá dí óto wán kíi.
DET concubine TNS ASP curse DET other one kill
‘The concubine was calling down a curse upon the other concubine.’

The DP dí kambósa is interpreted as the subject of both verbs and the DP dí óto wan is interpreted as the object of both verbs, although both DPs are only (overtly) realized as the argument of the first verb.
Patterns of tense and aspect marking in serial verb constructions in Saramaccan are quite complex. We first discuss tense marking and then aspect marking.

In Saramaccan (but not in all languages with serial constructions) tense is marked only once in the string. It can only occur in front of the first verb, as shown in (7a–b). Consecutive tense marking is also not grammatical (7c):

(7)
a. A bì jáka en púu.
3SG TNS chase 3SG remove
‘He had chased him away.’
b. *A jáka en bì púu.
3SG chase 3SG TNS remove
c. *A bì jáka en bì púu.
3SG TNS chase 3SG TNS remove

Aspect normally is only marked on the first verb (8a). It then expresses non-punctual – i.e., durative, habitual, or iterative – aspect and has scope over all subevents. If aspect is only marked on the second verb, as in (8b), it expresses durative aspect and has scope only over the second subevent. If, on the other hand, aspect is marked on both verbs, it can express durative and iterative aspect (8c). The iterative reading is preferred, however:

(8)
a. A tá fáa páu túe.
3SG ASP chop tree throw
‘He is felling a tree/the tree/trees.’
b. A fáa páu tá túe.
3SG chop tree ASP throw
‘He is felling the tree (i.e., at this very moment the tree is falling).’
c. A tá fáa páu tá túe.
3SG ASP chop tree ASP throw
‘He is (constantly) felling trees.’
Of these three ways of marking aspect in a serial verb construction, the second option, in which aspect is marked only on the second verb, is the least common.
Negation can be marked only once in the string and appears in front of the first verb and not in front of the second verb. This is shown in (9):

(9)
a. De á bì héngi en peeká a dí lakwa-páu.
3PL NEG TNS hang 3SG nail LOC DET cross
‘They didn't crucify him.’
b. *De bì héngi en á peeká a dí lakwa-páu.
3PL TNS hang 3SG NEG nail LOC DET cross

If an overt coordinating conjunction is present, not only the subject in the second conjunction has to be present but also the ‘shared’ object. This is impossible in serial verb constructions (cf. criteria in (5a–b)). The set of coordinating conjunctions includes hén ‘and’ and ma ‘but’. Relevant examples are given below:

(10)
a. A náki en hén a kíi en.
3SG hit 3SG and.then 3SG kill 3SG
‘He hit it and he killed it.’
b. *A náki en hén kíi en.
3SG hit 3SG and.then kill 3SG
c. *A náki en hén a kíi.
3SG hit 3SG and.then 3SG kill
Negation can occur in front of the second verb in this case:

(11)
A náki en ma á kíi en.
3SG hit 3SG but 3SG=NEG kill 3SG
‘He hit it, but he didn't kill it.’
Furthermore, the subject of the second conjunct does not have to be coreferential with the subject of the first conjunct. In other words, subject sharing is not obligatory:

(12)
A náki en hén mi kíi en.
3SG hit 3SG and.then 1SG kill 3SG
‘He hit it and (then) I killed it.’

A subordinating conjunction also cannot appear in the string. If it is present, an overt subject is possible before the second verb (cf. also Bickerton and Iatridou 1987); either referential as in (13b), or disjoint in reference from the matrix subject as in (13c):

(13)
a. A téi fáka u kóti dí beée.
3SG take knife FOR cut DET bread
‘He took the knife in order to cut the bread.’
b. A téi fáka faa kóti dí beée.
3SG take knife FOR=3SG cut DET bread
‘He took the knife in order to cut the bread.’
c. Dí wómi téi fáka fu dí mujée kóti dí beée.
DET man take knife FOR DET woman cut DET bread
‘The man took the knife for the woman to cut the bread.’
Examples (13a–b) show that the subject in front of the second verb can be optionally realized.

Semantic criteria have received much less attention in the study of verb serialization than the syntactic ones. One (obvious) reason for this is that, as we will see below, serial verb constructions do not form a homogeneous class from a semantic point of view.

Because they are by definition monoclausal, serial verb constructions necessarily express one proposition, assuming that a proposition is a (simple or complex) predication linked up to a single tense (cf. Rothstein 1983). Thus, a predication is the core of a proposition, as in Mary walks, where walks is predicated of Mary. Here walks is the (primary) predicate of the clause, and is anchored by the finiteness of the verb (in this case present tense).

An argument often cited in the literature (e.g., Jansen et al. 1978) for this assertion is the fact that a serial verb construction has one truth-value assigned to it, and no subpart of the construction can be independently negated by means of an adversative tag. Thus, the classical contrast is the following: 3

(14)
a. *A téi fáka kóti dí beée ma á kóti en.
3SG take knife cut DET bread but 3SG=NEG cut 3SG
‘He took a knife and cut the bread (but he did not cut it).’ [approx.]
b. A téi fáka fu kóti dí beée ma á kóti en.
3SG take knife FOR cut DET bread but 3SG=NEG cut 3SG
‘He took a knife (in order) to cut the bread (but he did not cut it).’
In sentences containing a subordination conjunction (14b), it is possible to negate the second VP independently. In a serial verb construction, on the other hand, it is not, as can be seen in (14a).

Serial verb constructions display a variety of readings, ranging from conjunctive and modificatory to causative (Muysken 1988; Larson 1991). It is possible to construct a scale of readings which runs from coordination to subordination (based on Fugier 1988):

(15)
Coordination Enumeration of two distinct events
I Two distinct events in tight juxtaposition
II One event and its consequence
III One event and the aim toward which it tends
IV Two concomitant events
V One event and its reformulation
VI One event and the way it is realized
Subordination One event, and the second one on the occasion of the first one
A similar classification can be found in the work of Bámgbósé (1974, 1986).

Although interesting in themselves for descriptive purposes, such schemes in general lack explanatory power. Awóyalé (1988) underscores this observation and makes a case for a semantic template of event composition that underlies and, in part, determines the limits on verb serialization in Yoruba. This template consists of three terms: a core event predicate that can be modified by modality and state predicates (Awóyalé 1988: 9). Modality predicates indicate how events are carried out or the manner in which events occur, and state predicates signify the outcome of events:
(16) MODALITY* EVENT* STATE*

The following combinations are predicted to exist by the template: [modality event], [event event], [event state], and [state state] (see Awóyalé 1988: 20–25 on the non-availability of [modality modality] and [modality state]). The following Saramaccan examples are given to clarify the different possibilities:

(17)
a. A [M tjá en] [E gó a dí dáata]. (modality event)
3SG carry 3SG go LOC DET doctor
‘He went to the doctor with her.’
b. A [E sindjó] [E nján]. (event event)
3SG sit.down eat
‘He sat down and ate.’
c. A [E náki en] [S kíi]. (event state)
3SG hit 3SG kill
‘He hit it dead.’
d. A [S bígi] [S pása mi]. (state state)
3SG big exceed 1SG
‘He is bigger than me.’

Although this is the most useful division so far into different semantic types of serial verb constructions, it remains to be seen what the implications are for the (structural) analysis of the construction. Is there one (semantic) analysis for the whole class of serial verb constructions or does every semantic type require its own analysis? Likewise, does every single semantic type correspond to a distinct syntactic structure, or is there one syntactic structure underlying all semantic types?

subsection.heading: 3 Classification
subsection.p: As noted above, the principal problem that serial verb constructions seem to pose for grammatical theory is how their lexical and their syntactic properties interact. On the one hand, they are clearly lexically constrained: verbs in a serial chain are in part lexically restricted, and they often appear to undergo thematic restructuring to form complex predicates. On the other hand, the individual verbs in the chain are clearly separate verbs assigning cases and thematic roles to intervening objects. What are the semantic relations between the verbs? How do the different verbs in the chain interact? Two possibilities come to mind:

(18)
a. The verbs undergo thematic restructuring and become one predicate semantically.
b. All verbs in the chain are separate predicates and the relation between them is one of adverbial modification.

There are several ways in which to approach this issue. On the basis of a surface-oriented taxonomy about the number of Infls in serial verb constructions, Awóyalé (1988) proposes to set up a division between (i) languages with clausal serial verb constructions (IP-serials), exhibiting relatively more independence between the different subevents denoted by the separate verbs and free lexical selection, and (ii) languages with phrasal serial verb constructions (VP-serials), exhibiting relatively less independence or thematic restructuring and a limited set of participating verbs. The set of languages with clausal serial verb constructions would include Saramaccan and Berbice Dutch. The set of languages with phrasal serial verb constructions would include Haitian and Papiamentu (cf. Déchaine 1993 on Haitian, Bendix 1972 on Papiamentu):

(19)
a. IP-serializing: Igbo, Izi, Anyi, Ijo, Saramaccan, Berbice Dutch
b. VP-serializing: Yoruba, Igala, Ogori, Ebira, Ewe, Igede, Twi, Haitian, Papiamentu

There are two observations to make with respect to this division. First, languages with clausal serial verb constructions also have phrasal serial verb constructions. Thus, Saramaccan-type languages constitute a superset, exhibiting both types (phrasal, clausal) of serial verb constructions, and Haitian-type languages are a subset, exhibiting only one type (phrasal) of serial verb constructions. The set of serializing languages with only the clausal type is not attested in the literature.

Second, the two factors to distinguish the different types of serial verb constructions – i.e., more vs. less independence between the different subevents, and free vs. restricted lexical selection – should give rise to four logically possible types of serial verb construction instead of the two mentioned. These four logical possibilities are schematically represented in (20): 4

(20)
Less independence between subevents More independence between subevents
Lexically constrained Type 1 (phrasal) Type 2
Lexically free Type 3 Type 4 (clausal)

The notion ‘restricted lexical selection’ refers to the fact that in many cases of verb serialization, we tend to find that one verb in the construction is drawn from a certain semantic or aspectual class and occurs in a ‘fixed’ position. The notion ‘free lexical selection’ refers to constructions in which there are no such restrictions.

The rather vague notion ‘more or less independent subevents’ refers to the event composition of the construction. Couched in Awóyalé's (1988) terms, it means that ‘less independent subevents’ involve combinations of modality or state predicates and event predicates and also combinations of two state predicates, while ‘more independent subevents’ involve combinations of event predicates only.

Within type 1/type 2 serial verb constructions, four major groups of meanings can be distinguished: directional, argument-introducing, aspectual, and degree-marking serial verbs. These four are arranged very roughly in the order of frequency in which these semantic categories are marked by serial verbs in different groups of creole languages. Then, within each semantic category, the typical verbs are listed, again in order of frequency, which encode a specific type of meaning. In the overview in (21) only the ‘fixed’ verb in serial verb constructions is mentioned:

(21)
Function
Verb
Meaning
Directional go Direction away
come Direction toward
surround Around
be Locative
Argument-introducing give Benefactive, dative
take Instrumental, comitative, object
say Finite complementizer
Aspectual finish Perfective
return Iterative
be Continuative
Degree pass Comparative, too much
suffice Enough
Next to the specific verbs in (21), in different languages yet other verbs can occur sometimes in serial verb constructions.
We will now turn to a description of the four types of serial verb constructions in Saramaccan.

subsection.heading: 3.1 Type 1 constructions
subsection.p: With regard to type 1, the following verbs in Saramaccan can be used non-initially in this sense:

(22)
Type
Token
Gloss
Meaning
Directional gó go Direction away
kó come Direction toward
lóntu surround Circumvention
kumútu come out Origin
dóu arrive End-point
Argument-introducing dá give Goal/recipient, benefactive, experiencer, source
táa say Finite complementizer
Aspectual kabá finish Completive
káá finish Already
Degree pása pass Comparative
móo more Comparative
pói spoil Excessive
Most of these verbs (the directionals are a notable exception) are susceptible to grammaticalization and/or reanalysis.

subsection.heading: 3.1.1 Directional
subsection.p: The verbs gó ‘go’ and kó ‘come’ in non-initial position are used to mark direction away from or toward a point of reference established in the discourse, which in most cases happens to be the speaker (Sebba 1987). They are in most cases used in combination with verbs of movement, Yoruba being a notable exception (cf. Awóyalé 1988). They can be accompanied by a locative PP, but need not be:

(23)
a. A kúle gó
3SG run go
‘He ran away.’
b. A wáka kó a mi písi
3SG walk come LOC 1SG yard
‘He walked to my yard.’
There is no restriction on the type of verb they combine with. In addition to non-ergative verbs (as in the previous example), ergative and transitive verbs can also occur in this position:

(24)
a. A kaí gó a dí baáku.
3SG fall go LOC DET hole
‘He fell into the hole.’
b. A túe dí súndju gó a dí mátu.
3SG throw DET dirt go LOC DET woods
‘He threw the dirt into the woods.’
The verb lóntu also specifies the direction of the action of the first verb:

(25)
a. Mi wáka lóntu dí wósu
1SG walk surround DET house
‘I walk around the house.’
b. A bì hái dí dóti zuntá
lóntu dí kólo gogó
3SG TNS haul DET dirt bring together surround DET cabbage base
‘He had put earth around the base of the cabbage.’

The verb kumútu marks the location where the participant comes from. The verb dóu signifies the termination and/or the end-point of the action described by the foregoing verbs. The usage of these verbs is exemplified in (26):

(26)
A wáka kumútu a mi písi gó a fóto dóu
3SG walk come.out LOC 1SG yard go LOC city arrive
‘He walked out of my yard to the city (and arrived there).’

Although direction is prototypically expressed by general movement verbs of the ergative type, like gó and kó, other verbs, specifically transitive ones, can also indicate direction. In those cases the direction expressed is more specific. For illustration, consider the following examples:

(27)
a. A kándi dí wáta gó
3SG tilt DET water go
‘He poured the water.’
b. A kándi dí wáta túe a dí fája
3SG tilt DET water throw LOC DET fire
‘He poured the water onto the fire.’
c. A kándi dí wáta butá a dí báta
3SG tilt DET water put LOC DET bottle
‘He poured the water into the bottle.’

Different verbs in the second position are used to distinguish different senses of the notion ‘pour’. Thus, the notion ‘pour’ in a general sense is expressed with gó as the second verb, the more specific notion ‘pour onto’ with the transitive verb túe as the second verb and ‘pour into’ with the locative verb butá in second position. 5

subsection.heading: 3.1.2 Argument-introducing
subsection.p: The argument-introducing group consists of two verbs: dá ‘give’ and táa ‘say’. They always appear in non-initial position.
Dá ‘give’ can introduce Goal/Recipient (GOAL), Benefactive (BEN), Experiencer (EXP), and Source (SOURCE) arguments. This is shown in the next set of examples, respectively:

(28)
a. A tjá sondí kó dá dí Faánsi sèmbè GOAL.
3SG carry thing come give DET French man
‘He presented something to the Frenchman.’
b. Séi wan ijsie dá mi! BEN.
sell DET ice-cream give 1SG
‘Sell an ice-cream for me!’
c. De maá dí fáka dá mi EXP.
3PL sharpen DET knife give 1SG
‘They sharpened the knife for me.’
d. De píndja dí móni dá hen pikí-pikí SOURCE.
3PL pinch DET money give 3SG small-small
‘They cheated a little money out of him.’
Táa, the suppleted form of the verb táki ‘say’, introduces finite clauses. It follows verbs of speech, cognition, and perception:

(29)
a. A táki táa á búnu.
3SG say say 3SG=NEG good
‘He said that it is not good.’
b. Mi sábi táa á búnu.
1SG know say 3SG=NEG good
‘I know that it is not good.’
c. Mi sí táa dí wómi kumútu a dí wósu.
1SG see say DET man come.out LOC DET house
‘I saw that the man had come out of the house.’
It can also mark direct speech:

(30)
Mi táki táa sáka hen búta!
1SG say say lower 3SG put
‘I said: put it down!’
In addition, it can be followed by fu ‘for’, as in the following example, which may be best characterized as a subjunctive complementizer:

(31)
I táki táa faa náki dí dágu.
2SG say say FOR=3SG hit DET dog
‘You told him to hit the dog.’

subsection.heading: 3.1.3 Aspectual
subsection.p: The aspectual subgroup consists of two elements: the verb kabá ‘finish’ and káá, a suppletive form of kabá. They both come as the non-initial verb in the construction. Kabá marks completive aspect. Káá has been reanalyzed as an adverb meaning ‘already’, and always appears at the right (most) periphery of the clause/sentence, the prototypical position for adverbs in Saramaccan:

(32)
a. Mi jabí dí dóo kabá.
1SG open DET door finish
‘I have finished opening the door.’
b. Mi jabí dí dóo káá.
1SG open DET door finish
‘I already opened the door.’

subsection.heading: 3.1.4 Degree
subsection.p: The degree subgroup has three members: pása ‘pass’, moó ‘more’, and pói ‘spoil’. Pása and moó are used in comparative constructions and pói is used to mark excessive degree.
Pása as well as moó in the comparative construction can be combined with both intransitive and transitive verbs, with no (detectable) difference in meaning: 6

(33)
a. A fátu pása/moó mi.
3SG fat pass/more 1SG
‘She is fatter than me.’
b. A bebé daán pása/moó mi.
3SG drink rum pass/more 1SG
‘He drinks more rum than me.’
c. A bebé daán pása/moó watá.
3SG drink rum pass/more water
‘He drinks more rum than water.’
It depends on the object of pása/moó whether the subject or the object of the higher verb is the object of comparison, as can be seen from (33b, c).
If pása follows a verb of movement, it retains its original meaning:

(34)
Mi wáka pása hen.
1SG walk pass 3SG
‘I walked past him.’
Arguably, these constructions are instances of directional serial verb constructions.
Moó, in addition, can also be used as a degree modifier inside DPs:

(35)
Dí moó hánse wan mi ké.
DET more beautiful one 1SG want
‘The more beautiful one I want.’
Pói ‘spoil’ mainly functions as a degree marker:

(36)
A fátu pói dá mi.
3SG fat spoil give 1SG
‘She is too fat for me.’
When combined with transitive verbs it can, in addition, retain more of its original meaning, as shown in (37):

(37)
De bì náki hen pói.
3PL TNS hit 3SG spoil
A: ‘They had beaten him excessively.’
B: ‘They had beaten it and it turned bad.’
The structure that makes the B-reading possible presumably is a type 3 construction.
The comparative construction with pása and móo has been fully grammaticalized and the verbs have lost most (if not all) of their verbal characteristics.

subsection.heading: 3.2 Type 2 constructions
subsection.p: Turning now to type 2 serial verb constructions, they also have a verb in a fixed position, but in contrast with type 1 constructions their event composition is more loosely interpreted. In Saramaccan such constructions are formed with causative verbs used in non-initial position, and the verb téi ‘take’ is used in first position:

(38)
Type
Token
Gloss
Meaning
causative mbéi make (Direct) causation
dá give (Indirect) causation
argument-introducing téi take Instrument, direct object, comitative

Like type 1 serial verb constructions, these are also susceptible to grammaticalization. Causative verbs mbéi and dá have been reanalyzed as complementizers. Téi, on the other hand, has not been reanalyzed.
The verb téi can introduce Instrumental, Comitative, and Theme arguments of the following verb. This is shown in (39):

(39)
a. A téi dí páu náki hen gbóó túe káá.
3SG take DET stick hit 3SG ideophone throw finish
‘He already had taken a stick and beaten him down with it.’
b. Mi téi hen gó a dí sikóutu.
1SG take 3SG go LOC DET police
‘I took it and went to the police with it.’
c. Me téi dí búku butá alá.
1SG=NEG take DET book put there
‘I didn't take the book and put it there.’
Causative constructions with mbéi ‘make’ as the second verb express direct causality:

(40)
Dí tjúba tá kái mbéi hen uwíi munjá tooná kó bè.
DET rain ASP fall make 3SG hair wet turn come red
‘It is raining so that her hair becomes wet and turns red.’

(41)
Egbert bebé daán hía pói mbéi a fiká a wósu.
Egbert drink rum much spoil make 3SG stay LOC house
‘Egbert drank too much rum, so that he stayed home.’
Thus, in (40) the fact that her hair becomes wet (and subsequently turns red) is caused (directly) by the rainfall. In all these cases, mbéi links two events each of which is expressed by a verb.
Causative constructions with dá as the second verb express indirect causality:

(42)
a. Dí mujée mbéi te dá dí míi bebé.
DET woman make tea give DET child drink
‘The woman made tea for the child to drink.’
b. A butá hen-seéi dá a fón ku schaak.
3SG put 3SG-self give 3SG beat with chess
‘He let himself be beaten by her at a game of chess.’
The action of the first verb creates a situation in which the action of the verb following dá can occur. Like mbéi, it also links two events.

subsection.heading: 3.3 Type 3 constructions
subsection.p: Resultative serial verb constructions constitute type 3 constructions. They partly correspond to particle–verb combinations in Germanic languages (cf. Sebba 1987). Although the position of the result-denoting verb is also more or less fixed (a non-initial position), they differ from type 1 constructions in that the list of participating verbs is (in principle) open-ended.

A non-exhaustive list of verbs that can occur in this position is: kíi ‘kill’, fáu ‘(make) unconscious’, téi ‘take’, túe ‘throw’, butá ‘put’, hói ‘hold’, púu ‘pull’, paajá ‘separate’, jabí ‘open’, and kísi ‘catch’. Some illustrative examples are:

(43)
a. De hói hen butá.
3PL hold 3SG put
‘They kept him under control.’
b. AIDS kísii hen kíi.
AIDS catch 3SG kill
‘He died from AIDS.’
c. Mi kísi dí fii otó téi a mámate.
1SG catch DET FOR=2SG story take LOC morning
‘I recorded your story in the morning.’
d. A boóko hen púu.
3SG break 3SG pull
‘He broke it off.’

Although the list of lexical verbs that participate in the construction is in principle open-ended, there is a kind of parallellism constraint on the transitivity of participating verbs, i.e., only the combination of two transitive or unaccusative verbs is possible (Veenstra 2004). The generalization with respect to possible verb combinations in the resultative construction in Saramaccan amounts then to the following:

(44)
a. NP1
VTRANS
NP2
VTRANS
(= 45a)
b. *NP1

(= 45b)

(45)
a. De sikópu hen kíi.
3PL kick 3SG kill
‘They kicked him dead.’
b. *De fáa dí páu kaí.
3PL chop DET tree fall
c. *De kaí kíi.
3PL fall kill
d. Dí wósu boóko kaí.
DET house break fall
‘The house is fallen apart.’
This type of constraint has not been documented for any of the serializing Kwa languages (see for Edo: Stewart 1998; Ewe: Collins 1993; Yoruba: Déchaine 1993; Akan: Campbell 1996a).

subsection.heading: 3.4 Type 4 constructions
subsection.p: In type 4 (clausal) constructions, anything goes as long as it is semantically and/or pragmatically apt. There are no restrictions on the list of participating verbs or on their position in the string:

(46)
A kísi dí fou náki kíi limbó bói njan.
3SG catch DET bird hit kill clean cook eat
‘He caught the bird, struck it dead, cleaned, cooked, and ate it.’

(47)
A súti hen fulá pása gó náki dí sitónu hén mi téi hen.
3SG shoot 3SG pierce pass go hit DET wall and.then 1SG take 3SG
‘He shot him and the bullet went through him and into the wall and then I took it.’

(46) illustrates a quite complex sequence of (five) events in which all the verbs share their arguments with the first verb (and with each other). This argument sharing is not obligatory, as shown by (47), which describes a shoot-out in Saramacca Street between a police officer and a criminal and the picking up of the bullet by a by-stander. Although the bullet is only overtly realized as the object of téi, it is interpreted as the subject of the verbs pása, gó, and náki.

subsection.heading: 4.1 Hierarchical relations
subsection.p: The hierarchical relations between the different NP arguments in a serial verb construction have received little attention so far and the discussion has been based only on data from Haitian. In this section we present data on the three types of serial verb constructions to show that the same hierarchical relations hold between the NPs in Saramaccan as in Haitian. But first we discuss the Haitian facts.

Veenstra (1997), partly based on Déchaine (1988b), discusses the relation between NP2 and XP3 in serial verb constructions in Haitian, and shows that this relation is asymmetrical: NP2 asymmetrically c-commands XP3. The tests to show the relation between the arguments are taken from Barss and Lasnik's (1986) seminal paper on double object constructions in English. They involve anaphor binding, quantifier binding, and the so-called ‘each ...the other’ construction.

The first test involves anaphoric binding. 7 In the following examples an asymmetry arises. The NP in the NP2-position can bind an anaphoric element in the XP3-position. The reverse, however, is not possible:

(48)
a. M pran Marii
montre tet-lii/lii
nan glas la.
1SG take Mary show HEAD–3SG/3SG LOC mirror DET
‘I showed Mary herself in the mirror.’
b. *M pran tet-lii/lii
montre Marii
nan glas la.
1SG take HEAD-3SG/3SG show Mary LOC mirror DET
The upshot is that the difference in grammaticality is due to the asymmetrical c-command relation that holds between NP2 and XP3.

The second test involves quantifier binding and gives the same result. In order for a pronoun to be bound by a quantified NP, it must be in the structural domain of that NP. Otherwise we have a weak crossover configuration and the bound pronoun reading is not possible:

(49)
a. M pran chak livi
montre mèt li.
1SG take each book show owner 3SG
‘I showed each book to its owner.’
b. *M pran liv li
montre chak elevi.
1SG take book 3SG show each student

The last test, based on the ‘each ...the other’ construction, only reinforces the point made above that there is an asymmetrical relation between the two object positions. The NP containing ‘the other’ must be in the domain of the NP containing ‘each’. The reverse is ungrammatical (cf. Déchaine 1988b):

(50)
a. M pran chak timoun voye paran lot la.
1SG take each child send parent other DET
‘I sent each child to the other's parent.’
b. *M pran chek lot la voye chak neg.
1SG take check other DET send each person

The tests above all point toward the same conclusion, namely that XP3 is in the domain of NP2 and that NP2 is outside the domain of XP3. In other words, an asymmetrical c-command relation holds between the two object positions in serial verb constructions (of the take-type) in Haitian.

Turning now to different types of serial verb constructions in Saramaccan, we show that the same generalization holds for all types. The test that we use in each case involves quantifier binding. In the following examples it is shown that a quantified NP occupying the NP2-position can bind a pronoun in the XP3-position (the (a)-examples). The reverse situation is not possible (the (b)-examples). (51) is a directional serial verb construction:

(51)
a. Mi mandá híniwan ómi-miíii
gó a dí tatá f’éni.
1SG send each man-child go LOC DET father for=3SG
‘I have sent each son to his father.’
b. *Mi mandá héni
tatá gó a híniwan ómi-miíii.
1SG send 3SG father go LOC each man-child
The following examples are both take-serials. In (52) the object of téi is the Theme argument of the second verb, and in (53) it is interpreted as the Instrument of the second verb:

(52)
a. Mi téi híniwan búkui
mánda gó a dí sikífi-ma f’éni.
1SG take each book send go LOC DET write-MA FOR=3SG
‘I have sent each book to its writer.’
b. *Mi téi héni
búku mánda gó a híniwan sikífi-mai.
1SG take 3SG book send go LOC each write-MA

(53)
a. Mi téi híniwan búkui
náki dí sikífi-ma f’éni.
1SG take each book hit DET write-MA FOR=3SG
‘I took each book and hit its writer with it.’
b. *Mi téi héni
búku náki híniwan sikífi-mai.
1SG take 3SG book hit each write-MA

The conclusion we draw from these data is that in serial verb constructions the different arguments stand in an asymmetric relation to one another, in a left-to-right fashion, i.e., NP2 (asymmetrically) c-commands XP3.

subsection.heading: 4.2 Concatenation principles
subsection.p: Three possible concatenation principles involved in the analysis of serial verb constructions have been formulated in the literature: subordination, adjunction, and coordination. 8

subsection.heading: 4.2.1 Subordination
subsection.p: The possibility that verb serialization involves some form of subordination was mentioned as early as the mid-1970s. Schachter (1974), Jansen et al. (1978), and Sebba (1987), among others, couched their analysis in terms of subordination. More recent analyses, like Baker (1989, 1991b), Lefebvre (1991), and Sybesma (1997), also adhere to this way of relating the different VPs in serial verb constructions. Arguments for this supposition are the extractability of arguments and the (sometimes) close semantic relationship between the verbs in serial verb constructions, which quite often seems to be comparable to the relation between verbs and prepositions in [V PP]-constructions.

An argument against this hypothesis is constituted by the arrangement of the verbs in a serial verb construction. How are the verbs in the chain placed in a specific order? In the case of subordination an arrangement determined by the Head Parameter would be a plausible answer. The comparison of serial verb constructions in Sranan and Ijo suggests that the matter must be more complicated. (54) shows that Ijo is head-final: 9

(54)
a. keni bila eri mi [[NP V] I]
an elephant see TNS
‘saw an elephant’
b. bele bi o nama tua mi [[[[NP P] NP] V] I]
pot DET in meat put TNS
‘put meat in the pot’
c. Ari u di yo-koo bo mi. [[[IP C] V] I]
1SG 3SGM look.at in.order.to come TNS
‘I came in order to see him.’
The same direction holds for [NP V] in (54a), for [[PP NP] V] in (54b), and for [CP V] in (54c). Note also that temporal marking is completely to the right in all cases, thus [VP I].
Sranan is a strict head-initial language:

(55)
a. koti a brede [V NP]
cut DET bread
‘cut the bread’
b. poti a brede a tafra tapu [V [NP [P NP]]]
put DET bread LOC table top
‘put the bread on the table’
c. Eddy e koti a brede fu nyan en [I [V [C IP]]]
Eddy ASP cut DET bread FOR eat 3SG
‘Eddy is cutting the bread in order to eat it.’

Nonetheless it turns out that the order of the verbs in serial verb constructions in both languages is the same, in a number of constructions. Take first of all the take serial verb constructions in (56) and (57), which also illustrate the very extensive possibilities of use of this construction:

(56)

a. Ye aki u bee.

‘Say something to him.’
b. Aru bi aki tin kaka.
canoe DET take tree tie
‘Tie the canoe to a tree.’

(57)

a. No teki baskita tyari watra.
NEG take basket carry water
‘Don't carry water with a basket.’
b.
Teki dia poti na brakoto.
take deer put LOC barbecue
‘Put the deer on the grill.’
The same holds for the give serial verb constructions in (58) and (59):

(58)

a. Duma tun-ni a piri.
song sing 3SGF give
‘Sing a song for her.’
b. Egberi gba-ni u piri.

‘Tell him a story.’

‘Send a message to Tiger/send Tiger a message.’
b. prani a karu gi yu

‘plant the corn for you’
Furthermore, degree-marking serial verb constructions, such as the comparative serial, involve the same order of the verbs in both languages:

(60)

‘ran faster than the child’

(61)

Kofi big surpass Kwasi
‘Kofi is bigger than Kwasi.’
Finally, directional serial verb constructions involve the same order as well:

(62)

3SGM turn come TNS
‘He returned, he came back.’

A waka kon.
3SG walk come
‘S/he walked this way.’

The fact that the arrangement of the elements in the serial construction is independent of the Head Parameter suggests that there is no relation between the verbs stated in terms typical of subordination.

In addition, in a subordination-type analysis the first verb would select the second VP. Thus, a semantic relationship should hold between V1 and VP2. But with respect to resultative serial verb constructions, it is not all clear how the first verb in any relevant way would semantically select the second VP. We here revert to Saramaccan examples:

(64)
a. Mi náki hén kíi.
1SG hit 3SG kill
‘I struck him dead.’
b. Mi sáka dí lái butá alá.
1SG lower DET load put over.there
‘I have put the load over there.’

It is difficult to conceive of the type of semantic role that náki in (64a) or sáka in (64b) would assign, respectively, to kíi or to butá alá. Moreover, such a move would mean that practically all verbs in Saramaccan (or any other serializing language for that matter) have the ability to select a predicate in addition to a nominal argument, presumably an unwarranted complication of the lexicon (and grammar) of serializing languages.
If one assumes that the first verb selects a constituent consisting of NP2 and VP2 (cf. Den Dikken 1991a; Sybesma 1997), moreover, several other problems arise:

(65)
A téi [dí beée kóti].
3SG take DET bread cut
‘He cut the bread.’

Semantically, the verb téi ‘take’ (in the sense of seize and physically grasp) does not take a proposition-denoting category as a complement. One does not seize or physically grasp a proposition. Although some verbs may take an argument that has some specific semantic property, regardless of its category, the verb téi ‘take’ in Saramaccan is arguably not one of them. For example, the verb ask in English takes either a clausal or a nominal argument, and both of them are of the same semantic type, namely a question (cf. Grimshaw 1979) (the time in (66) is also known as a concealed question):

(66)
a. John asked Mary what time it was.
b. John asked Mary the time.
The verb téi, in contrast, can syntactically take a nominal argument, as shown in (67) (in which it is not a serial verb construction):

(67)
A téi dí fáka.
3SG take DET knife
‘He took the knife.’

but the nominal argument of the verb téi is clearly not something that denotes a proposition. Therefore, if the verb may take an XP which is either a VP as suggested in (65) or an NP as in (67), with the two categories being of different semantic types, then it seems unavoidable that we have to posit two different verbs téi in the lexicon of Saramaccan.

subsection.heading: 4.2.2 Adjunction
subsection.p: The second possible candidate is adjunction. In this type of analyses the second VP is adjoined to the first. Such structures have been proposed by Bickerton and Iatridou (1987), Larson (1991), Seuren (1991), and Law and Veenstra (1992).
Evidence for the adjunct status of the non-initial VP is its optionality, as shown below:

(68)
a. A téi dí páu tjá gó butá a dí wósu.
3SG take DET stick carry go put LOC DET house
‘He took the stick, carried it away and put it in the house.’
b. A téi dí páu tjá gó.
3SG take DET stick carry go
‘He took the stick and carried it away.’
c. A téi dí páu.
3SG take DET stick
‘He took the stick.’
Hence, the third VP is not selected by the second verb and the second VP is not selected by the first verb.

Larson (1991) also makes some semantic observations that lend plausibility to analyses that treat serial verb constructions as adjoining structures. In particular, he notes that serial verb constructions in many cases form series of secondary predications with a basic modificatory status, and have similar readings as adverbial conjuncts involving ‘until’ or expressing purpose and temporal adverbials. Adverbials presumably have an adjunct status. Moreover, he notes that such structures can accommodate the semantic templates of Awóyalé (1988).

Veenstra (1993) builds an argument for adjunction on patterns of argument and adjunct extraction. In contrast to arguments, adjuncts cannot be extracted from the non-initial VP in serial verb constructions (cf. also Lawal 1993 on Yoruba). He shows that these facts can be accommodated in an adjunction structure without the need of additional assumptions, unlike an analysis in term of subordination. Moreover, he shows that serial verb constructions pattern differently than small clause and perception verb complements (instances of subordination structures) with respect to wh-extraction. In conclusion, a good case can be made for adjunction as the guiding principle for the stacking of VPs in serial verb constructions. 10

subsection.heading: 4.2.3 Coordination
subsection.p: Coordination structures come in four varieties. Two factors discriminate the four varieties: syndetic vs. asyndetic and symmetrical vs. asymmetrical.

Syndetic coordinations contain a conjunction and asyndetic coordinations do not. As already shown in section 3, serial verb constructions cannot contain (coordinating) conjunctions. This rules out the possibility that serial verb constructions are instances of syndetic coordinations. It leaves open the possibility, however, that they are asyndetic coordinations.

Symmetrical coordinations do not show sequential effects and asymmetrical ones do. A frequently cited argument in favor of a coordination analysis is that in (some) serial verb constructions there is a temporal ordering between the different actions (or subevents):

(69)
a. Mi wáka gó a dí wósu.
1SG walk go LOC DET house
‘I walked to the house.’
b. *Mi gó a dí wósu wáka.
1SG go LOC DET house walk

(70)
a. Mi téi dí fáka kóti dí beée.
1SG take DET knife cut DET bread
‘I took the knife and cut the bread.’
b. *Mi kóti dí beée téi dí fáka.
1SG cut DET bread take DET knife

(71)
a. Mi náki hén kíi.
1SG hit 3SG kill
‘I struck him dead.’
b. *Mi kíi hén náki.
1SG kill 3SG hit

The sequential effect shows up in all three types. These data rule out an analysis of serial verb constructions in terms of symmetrical coordination. They leave open the possibility that these constructions are asymmetrical coordinations. The conclusion, therefore, is that if serial verb constructions have a coordinate structure, they are asyndetic asymmetric coordinations (cf. Déchaine 1993).

A coordinate analysis has been argued against by Jansen et al. (1978) and Sebba (1987). They show that serial verb constructions never show the island effects that have been associated with coordinate structures since Ross (1986). In particular, all the VPs in serial verb constructions are transparent with respect to argument extraction:

(72)
Na-un-séi
a wáka gó ti?
LOC-Q-side 3SG walk go
‘Where did he walk to?’

(73)
a. Andíi
a téi ti
kóti dí beée?
what 3SG take
cut DET bread
‘What did he cut the bread with?’
b. Andíi
a téi dí fáka kóti ti?
what 3SG take DET knife cut
‘What did he cut with the knife?

(74)
Ambéi
a náki ti
kíi?
who 3SG hit
kill
‘Who did he strike dead?’

However, the argument is not as strong as it appears to be at first sight. The Coordinate Structure Constraint (CSC) of Ross (1986) is enforced for those coordinations that are (semantically) symmetric. No extraction is allowed out of the conjuncts, unless it is in an Across-the-Board (ATB) fashion, i.e., simultaneous extraction out of all conjuncts. We have already pointed out above that if serial verb constructions are anything like coordinations, they are asymmetric coordinations. Thus, the absence of island effects is not a direct argument against an analysis in terms of asymmetric coordination.

The pattern of extraction out of asymmetric coordinations is as follows (cf. Williams 1994). Extraction out of the second conjunct is allowed. Extraction out of the first conjunct is not possible, unless it happens in an ATB fashion. Relevant examples from English are given in (75):

(75)
a. Whati did John go to New York and buy ti?
b. *What cityi did John go to ti and buy a gun?
An example of an ATB extraction out of an asymmetric coordination structure in English is (76):
(76) Whoi did you see ti and imitate ti?
Schematically, we can represent the different extraction possibilities out of asymmetric coordination structures and serial verb constructions as follows:

(77)
Asymmetric coordination:
a. WHi [VP1 V XP] [VP2 V eci]
b.* WHi [VP1 V eci] [VP2 V XP]
c. WHi [VP1 V eci] [VP2 V eci]

(78)
Serial verb construction:
a. WHi [VP1 V NP] [VP2 V eci]
b. WHi [VP1 V eci] [VP2 V XP]
In an asymmetric coordination analysis of serial verb constructions, the pattern in (78b) constitutes the problem. Contrary to our expectations, you can extract out of the first conjunct.

Suppose now that we reduce this pattern to the pattern in (77c) by positing an empty category in the non-initial conjunct coreferent with the object in the initial conjunction. Then, (78b) rewrites as (79):
(79) WHi [VP1 V eci] [VP2 V eci XP]

Thus, what looks like extraction out of the first conjunct only is in fact a form of ATB extraction. The conclusion, therefore, is that serial verb constructions can be reduced to asymmetric coordination structures iff there is an empty category present in the second VP coreferent with the object of the first verb.

Arguments for the presence of an empty category inside the non-initial predicate of serial verb constructions have been presented by Bickerton and Iatridou (1987), Carstens (1988), Larson (1991), Law and Veenstra (1992), DeGraff (1993), Collins (1993, 1997a), Veenstra (1993, 1996), Da Cruz (1994), Campbell (1996a), Stewart (1998), and Hagemeijer (2000).

Munn (1992) argues that ATB constructions should be reduced to parasitic gap constructions. Although coordinate structures behave differently from structures supporting parasitic gaps, the point he makes is that multiple gap constructions in both structures are best analyzed in terms of null operator binding and chain composition. He notes that a consequence of such an analysis is that “coordinate structures are in fact adjunction structures with a hierarchical and therefore asymmetric structure” (Munn 1992: 1). This conception of coordinate structures tallies nicely with the analyses of serial verb constructions put forward by Larson (1991) and Law and Veenstra (1992), in which the second predicate is an adjunct to the first predicate and in which the argument-sharing effect is obtained through null operators.

The conclusion, therefore, is that a good case can be made for the analysis of serial verb constructions in terms of asyndetic asymmetric coordination structures (cf. Corne et al. 1996 for a similar conclusion), with coordination being syntactically analyzed in terms of an adjunction structure, with the provision that it can be shown that an empty category is present inside the non-initial predicate that is adjoined to the first predicate.

subsection.heading: 5 Argument sharing
subsection.p: An observation that goes back to Stewart (1963) is that overt objects in serial verb constructions are semantically related to both verbs, i.e., the verbs share their internal arguments. Thus, in (80a) the object dí búku ‘the book’ is an object of téi ‘take’ as well as of léi ‘show’:

(80)
a. Mi téi dí búku léi dí wómi.
1SG take DET book show DET man
‘I showed the book to the man.’
b. Mi téi dí fáka kóti dí beée.
1SG take DET knife cut DET bread
‘I cut the bread with the knife.’
For example, in (80b) it has been argued that dí fáka ‘the knife’ is the Instrument object of the second verb kóti.

The question is whether the (semantic or syntactic) sharing of arguments is obligatory in verb serialization. Sebba (1987) discusses the following minimal pair and argues that only if the verbs share their object is it possible to speak of a serial verb construction:

(81)
a. A náki hén kíi.
3SG hit 3SG kill
‘She hit him dead.’
b. A náki hén kíi hén.
3SG hit 3SG kill 3SG
‘She hit him and killed him.’
Sebba argues at length that (81b) involves a coordinate structure and displays a distinct behavior from that of (81a).

The most explicit answer to the question of the obligatoriness of object sharing has been formulated in the work of Baker (1989, 1991b). For him, the sharing of arguments is one of the defining properties of the construction. Moreover, this sharing is not at random, but is thematically restricted; i.e., in serial verb constructions with more than one internal argument, as in (80), the order in which arguments appear obeys the following thematic hierarchy:
(82) Ag < Instr < . . . < Th < Go < Loc

If the second verb selects a Theme and an Instrument, it is only the Instrument that can be shared with the first verb. Similarly, if the second verb is a regular triadic verb, it is the Theme that is shared with the first verb rather than the Goal. This restriction might cover in principle the observed facts for some serializing languages, such as Yoruba and Gokana. Relevant examples are given in (83) and (84), taken from Baker (1989) and Wagner (1985), respectively:

(83)
a. Olú mú òbe gé búrédi.
Olu take knife cut bread
‘Olu cut the bread with the knife.’
b. *Olú mú búrédi gé òbe.
Olu take bread cut knife

(84)
a. mín è tú kpá nè pábia.
child TNS take book give woman
‘The child gave the book to the woman.’
b. *mín è tú pábia nè kpá.
child TNS take woman give book

On the other hand, it is too restrictive for other languages, such as Haitian, Sranan, and Saramaccan (cf. Law and Veenstra 1992; Veenstra 1993). The following data, which are direct counter-examples to the thematic restriction on argument sharing in verb serialization, suffice to make the point:

(85)
a. Mi téi dí fáka kóti dí beée.
1SG take DET knife cut DET bread
b. Mi téi dí beée kóti ku dí fáka.
1SG take DET bread cut with DET knife
‘I cut the bread with the knife.’
c. *Mi téi dí beée kóti dí fáka.
1SG take DET bread cut DET knife

(86)
a. A téi dí fóto léi hen.
3SG take DET picture show 3SG
a. A téi hen léi dí fóto.
3SG take 3SG show DET picture
‘He showed the picture to him.’

Thus, it appears that the cross-linguistic variation with respect to the ordering of arguments in serial verb constructions is rather due to language-specific constraints than to universal ones on the process of serialization.

subsection.heading: 6 Parameterization and typological correlates
subsection.p: As noted in section 1, if there exists something like a serializing language type we would expect a number of typological correlates (i.e., co-occurring linguistic features) of serial verb constructions. The following have been put forward as possible correlates: word order, non-distinctiveness of verbs and prepositions, absence of verbal (derivational or inflectional) morphology, and separation of verbs from INFL.

subsection.heading: 6.1 Word order
subsection.p: This is not promising. The Caribbean creole languages are all SVO languages, but many West African serializing languages are underlyingly SOV (as shown in work inspired by Koopman 1984), and some are SOV on the surface as well, like Ijo. Malagasy is verb-initial, and in the Pacific and Sino-Tibetan cases we find both SOV and SVO languages.

subsection.heading: 6.2 Non-distinctiveness of verbs and prepositions
subsection.p: Proposals that verb serialization is correlated with non-distinctiveness of verbs and prepositions come into two guises: verbs are seen either as additional Case markers (e.g., Bickerton 1981; Byrne 1987) or as additional markers of thematic roles (e.g., Sebba 1984). With respect to the latter proposal, Bruyn et al. (1999) have shown that (virtually) all creole languages have double object constructions, thereby casting doubt on Sebba's (1984) claim that verbs in serializing languages can select only one internal argument at the time. The former proposal assumes that serializing languages do not have prepositions and that this gap is taken over by verbs. Problems with this type of approach are manifold. First, serial verbs allow stranding, just like verbs; prepositions (in Sranan and Haitian) generally do not:

(87)
a. San Edgar koti
___? Sranan
what Edgar cut
‘What did Edgar cut?’
b. San Edgar teki
___ koti a brede?
what Edgar take
cut DET bread
‘What did Edgar cut the bread with?’
c. *A nefi san a e koti a brede nanga
___?
DET knife that 3SG ASP cut DET bread with
Second, (some) serial verbs allow predicate cleft, just like verbs, and prepositions never do:

(88)
a. Na koti
Edgar koti
a brede. Sranan
BE cut Edgar cut DET bread
‘Edgar really cut the bread.’
b. Na teki
Edgar teki
a nefi koti a brede.
BE take Edgar take DET knife cut DET bread
‘Really with the knife Edgar cut the bread.’
c. *Na nanga
Edgar koti a brede nanga
a nefi.
BE with Edgar cut DET bread with DET knife

Third, some creole languages (e.g., Principense) distinguish oblique (assigned by P) from objective case (assigned by V). Fourth, all creole languages have a number of prepositions without verbal properties. Finally, serial verbs are also used non-prepositionally.

subsection.heading: 6.3 Absence of verbal morphology and separation of verbs from INFL
subsection.p: For Saramaccan, and creole languages in general (for West African languages the issue is not as clear), we want to suggest that absence of verbal morphology (or the inertia of it, if present, as in some West African languages) and the separation of verbs and INFL are interrelated. In general, creole languages lack verbal morphology (i.e., verbs do not inflect for tense, number, and person). They also lack V-to-I movement. It could be argued that the absence of V-to-I movement sets serializing languages, apart from non-serializing languages, which have V-to-I movement in overt syntax or at LF.

The discussion in section 4 led to the conclusion that all serial verb constructions are to be analyzed as right-adjoined structures, i.e., the second predicate is adjoined to the first predicate. If there is no verb movement to INFL in serializing languages because of the lack of tense/agreement morphology on the verb, then, as a result, the verb in the second predicate of a serial verb construction need not move to INFL. In other words, the structure of serial verb constructions, as given in (89), is legitimate in serializing languages (omitting details irrelevant for the discussion at hand):
(89) [NPi [ti V1 [VP1 NP2 t1 [VP2 V2 XP3]]]]

The question of why non-serializing languages like English and French do not have serial verb constructions now hinges on the question of why they disallow the structure in (89). Notice that non-serializing languages usually have richer inflectional morphology in terms of tense, number, and person agreement than serializing languages. Suppose that the verb in languages with some verbal inflection must move to INFL (via Tense) to pick up inflectional morphology in overt syntax or at LF, then in the structure in (89), movement of the second verb out of the second predicate would violate Travis's (1984) Head Movement Constraint (HMC):

(90)
Head Movement Constraint:
An X0 may only move to the Y0 which properly governs it.

In the structure in (89), the second verb heads a complement neither to the first verb nor to Tense. Therefore, there are two possible reasons why serial verb constructions are not possible in non-serializing languages: either because the second verb fails to get inflectional morphology, if it does not move out of the second VP, or because the movement of the second verb to INFL to get inflectional morphology would violate the HMC, since the trace left by movement of the second verb is not properly governed.

This account of the availability of serial verb constructions in languages fares better than the account given by Larson (1991). He proposes that serializing languages differ from non-serializing ones in that in the former set of languages, secondary predicates are essentially non-nominal (either [−N] or [+V] but not [+N, −V]) in nature, while in the latter set, secondary predicates are non-verbal (either [+N] or [−V] but not [−N, +V]) in nature (see Larson 1991: 205–207 for more details and argumentation). One clear-cut prediction of his proposal is that serializing languages do not have secondary predicates headed by nouns, e.g., NP predicates in small clauses. (91) gives direct counter-examples:

(91)
a. Mi féndi en bumbúu sèmbe.
1SG find 3SG good person
‘I consider him a good person.’
b. A tá lúku mi ógi-wójo.
3SG ASP look 1SG evil-eye
‘She looks at me angrily.’
These accounts (i.e., Larson 1991; Law and Veenstra 1992) assume a modular solution to the issue of why certain languages have serial verb constructions and others do not have them.

Baker (1989, 1991b), on the other hand, opts for a parametric approach. He starts out by discussing the Head-Licensing Condition (HLC) of Chomsky (1986b). The HLC requires a head to be linked to a single maximal projection. This gives way to the possibility of one maximal projection licensing two head positions. Consequently, Baker proposes that the key difference between serializing and non-serializing languages lies in the exploitation of this possibility. He recasts it in the following parameter (Baker 1989: 519):

(92)
Generalized Serialization Parameter:
VPs {can/cannot} count as the projection of more than one distinct head.

Languages such as Saramaccan and Haitian allow for a positive value of this parameter and, therefore, have serial verb constructions, while languages such as French and English do not and, as a consequence, do not have serial verb constructions. One of the main problems of this approach is that it has to posit parametric differences in specific phrase structure rules, contra the spirit of Stowell (1981) and later work.

Collins (1995a) relates the possibility of having serial verb constructions to a parameter on the feature-specification of Tense. If the V-feature of Tense is [+multiple], it is a serializing language. The V-feature of Tense in non-serializing languages is [−multiple]. Such an approach would account for the same range of facts as the approach advocated by Law and Veenstra (1992). It would lose the correlation with lack of verb movement (in overt syntax and at LF), however. In a multiple feature-specification type of analysis the verb still has to move at some point in the derivation to Tense to check off the V-feature. 11

It appears, then, that the difference between serializing and non-serializing languages derives from differences between languages with respect to the availability/richness of tense/agreement morphology. In this way parametric variation is reduced to different properties of functional categories and their interaction with independently motivated assumptions concerning verbal syntax, a desirable result in view of the task of acquiring language (Ouhalla 1991).

Schachter 1974):

subsection.p: We leave this speculation for future research, but note that it is not a priori necessary that all serializing languages should form a natural class.
